casebody.data:
DORLAND v. FIDELITY DEVELOPMENT CO. et al. (ROBIN, Intervener). (Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department. February 13, 1914.) Appeal and Error (§ 91*)—Right to Appeal. An order granting a motion for leave to intervene as a defendant will be affirmed on appeal, if the order does not affect a substantial right of the defendants appealing therefrom. [Ed. Note.—For other cases, see Appeal and Error, Cent. Dig. §§ 612-641; Dec. Dig. § 91.*] Appeal from Special Term, New York County. Action by Louise M. Borland, a creditor, on behalf of herself, against the Fidelity Development Company, impleaded with others. From an order granting a motion of Joseph G. Robin for leave to intervene, the Development Company and others appeal. Affirmed.

Argued before INGRAHAM, P. J., and McLAUGHLIN, LAUGH-LIN, CLARKE, and SCOTT, JJ..

Robert McC. Marsh, of New York City, for appellants. Robert D. Ireland, of New York City, for respondent. PER CURIAM.

The order appealed from is affirmed, with $10 costs and disbursements, upon the ground that the order granted does not affect a substantial right of the appellants.
